title: Australian Popular Baby Names
text: ozbabynames package provides dataset ozbabynames. contains popular Australian baby names sex, state year.
code: library(ozbabynames) head(ozbabynames) #>        name    sex year count           state #> 1 Charlotte Female 2017   577 New South Wales #> 2    Olivia Female 2017   550 New South Wales #> 3       Ava Female 2017   464 New South Wales #> 4    Amelia Female 2017   442 New South Wales #> 5       Mia Female 2017   418 New South Wales #> 6      Isla Female 2017   392 New South Wales

title: Australian Popular Baby Names
text: can install released version ozbabynames github:

title: Australian Popular Baby Names
text: babynames - US baby names 1880 2017. nzbabynames - New Zealand baby names 1900 2017. norwaynames - Norway baby names 1880 2017.

title: Australian Popular Baby Names
text: let’s look popularity package author names, “Rob”, “Mitchell”, “Nicholas”, “Jessie”, well similar names.  let’s see animated
code: library(ggplot2) library(dplyr)  ozbabynames_1952_top_10 <- ozbabynames |>   filter(year == 1952) |>   group_by(sex, name) |>   summarise(count = sum(count)) |>   arrange(-count) |>   top_n(10) |>   ungroup()  ggplot(ozbabynames_1952_top_10,        aes(x = reorder(name, count),            y = count,            group = sex)) +   geom_col() +   facet_grid(sex ~ .,               scales = "free_y") +   coord_flip() +   ylab("Count") + xlab("Name") +   ggtitle("Top ten male and female names in 1952") author_names <- c("Robin", "Robert", "Mitchell", "Nicholas", "Jessie", "Jessica")  ozbabynames |>   filter(name %in% author_names) |>   group_by(name, year) |>    summarise(count = sum(count)) |>    ggplot(aes(x = year,               y = count,              colour = name)) +   geom_line() +   theme_bw() +   facet_wrap(~name,              scales = "free_y") +   theme(legend.position = "none") library(gganimate)  ozbabynames |>   filter(name %in% author_names) |>   count(name,year, wt = count) |>   ggplot(aes(x = year,               y = n,              colour = name,              group = name,              label = name,              fill = name)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1, linetype = "dotted") +   geom_label(colour = "white", alpha = 0.75, size =  5) +   theme_bw() +   theme(panel.grid = element_blank(),         legend.position = "none",         title = element_text(colour = "purple",                              size = 20,                              face = "bold")         ) +   labs( title = "number of bubs dubbed in {frame_along} ",         y = "n babies" ) +   scale_y_log10(labels = scales::comma) +   transition_reveal(along = year)

title: Australian Popular Baby Names
text: coverage uneven, states providing recent data, states providing top 50 100 names. ACT provide counts, ACT data included. South Australia far best data, full coverage names back 1944.

what: ozbabynames: Popular Australian baby names. — ozbabynames
title: ozbabynames: Popular Australian baby names. — ozbabynames
text: ozbabynames package provides data object `ozbabynames` containing popular Australian baby names sex, state year. coverage uneven, states providing recent data, states providing top 50 100 names. ACT provide counts, ACT data included. South Australia far best data, full coverage names back 1944.

title: ozbabynames: Popular Australian baby names. — ozbabynames
ozbabynames: Popular Australian baby names. — ozbabynames
ozbabynames: Popular Australian baby names. — ozbabynames
ozbabynames: Popular Australian baby names. — ozbabynames
code: head(ozbabynames) #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>   name      sex     year count state           #>   <chr>     <chr>  <int> <int> <chr>           #> 1 Charlotte Female  2017   577 New South Wales #> 2 Olivia    Female  2017   550 New South Wales #> 3 Ava       Female  2017   464 New South Wales #> 4 Amelia    Female  2017   442 New South Wales #> 5 Mia       Female  2017   418 New South Wales #> 6 Isla      Female  2017   392 New South Wales  # Plot most popular names in 2016 library(ggplot2) library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union ozbabynames %>% filter(year==2016) %>%   group_by(sex,name) %>%   summarise(count = sum(count)) %>%   arrange(-count) %>%   top_n(10) %>%   ungroup() %>%   ggplot(aes(x=reorder(name, count), y=count, group=sex)) +     geom_bar(stat='identity') +     facet_grid(sex ~ ., scales = "free_y") +     coord_flip() +     ylab("Count") + xlab("Name") +     ggtitle("Top ten male and female names in 2016") #> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'sex'. You can override using the `.groups` #> argument. #> Selecting by count
